doc.title: Mexico QIR: Firmer 2025-26 Real Activity Outlook but Output Gap Projected to Move Deeper Into Negative Territory (Ramos)
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Mexico QIR Firmer 2025-26 Real Activity Outlook but Output Gap Projected to Move Deeper Into Negative Territory Ramos Me_2025-08-29

passages.text: Bottom- Line: The 2Q25 Inflation Report Q- QIR) is consistent with the policy signals conveyed at the Aug 7 MPC meeting and the respective minutes. The MPC became more upbeat on growth for 2025 (+50bp to just \(0.6\%\) and also 2026 (+20bp to \(1.1\%\) ). Following the firmer 2Q25 real GDP print the output gap is tracking at \(- 0.8\%\) of GDP (not as wide as the previous \(- 1.5\%\) forecast) and is forecasted to widen to \(- 1.9\%\) (vs \(- 2.5\%\) in the previous report) in 2025 and to \(- 3.0\%\) (vs \(- 3.6\%\) in the previous report) in 2026. The MPC forecasts show headline/core inflation reaching \(3.7 / 3.7\%\) by end- 2025 with convergence to the \(3.0\%\) target achieved by 3Q2026 (which we deem as too optimistic). A principal component analysis shows that slack conditions in consumption markets remain in negative territory (- 0.7%) and that the labor market remains tight (labor market slack at \(+0.8\%\) ). The balance of risks for inflation around the projected path "remains biased to the upside" (though less so than in 2021- 2024) and the balance of risks for activity is "biased to the downside." For the central bank, the US economic policy changes have added uncertainty to the forecasts, and their effects could imply pressures on inflation on both sides of the balance of risks. One of the analytical boxes shows that the behavior of monthly inflation and its volatility are currently similar to the pre- pandemic period, which suggests that the pandemic- related shocks have faded. In our assessment, the policy signal from this analytical study is dovish for future monetary policy decisions.

Policy Implications: At the Aug 7 meeting, MPC cut the policy rate by 25bp to \(7.75\%\) in a split 4- 1 decision. Director Jonathan Heath dissented in favor of no cut. The forward guidance hints at additional rate cuts: "looking ahead, the MPC will assess further adjustments to the policy rate." The ex- ante real policy rate is now tracking at around \(4.0\%\) , still above the \(3.6\%\) upper- limit of the estimated neutral range, and sub- trend growth is expected to keep the output gap in negative territory through end 2026. In our assessment, the MPC has been downplaying high core- goods inflation and services inflation stickiness and seems inclined to continue to normalize monetary policy and keep the Mex- US interest rate differential tighter than the historical norm. There was no mention in the statement of policy neutrality or the terminal rate. We forecast another 25bp rate cut at the Sept meeting and expect the policy rate to reach \(7.25\%\) by end- 2025.

The QIR contains a few analytical boxes, of which we highlight one, with dovish implications for monetary policyâ€”an econometric study analyzing the generalization of inflation and its volatility after and before the Covid- 19 pandemic following the

approach in Hornstein, et al. (2024). The study finds that the behavior of monthly inflation and its volatility are currently similar to that observed pre- pandemic, which suggests that the pandemic related shocks have faded. In our assessment, this study offers econometric support to further normalization of monetary policy.

1. The MPC upgraded the forecasts for real GDP growth in 2025/26. The growth forecast for 2025 was upgraded by 50bp, to just \(0.6\%\) (midpoint of the \(0.1\%\) to \(+1.1\%\) interval), from \(0.1\%\) (midpoint of the \(-0.5\%\) to \(+0.7\%\) interval) in the previous QIR, a reflection of firmer 2Q25 growth (lighter-than-expected impact of US trade policy changes and related uncertainty on exports and domestic demand). For 2026 the central bank growth forecast increased by 10bp to \(1.1\%\) \((0.3\% -1.9\%)\) , vs \(0.9\%\) \((0.1\% -1.7\%)\) in the previous report. The central bank anticipates "low growth" during 2H2026 and a moderate expansion in 2026. The central bank continues to anticipate a "limited impact" of US import tariffs on Mexican exports.

2. Despite firmer 1Q25 real activity, the output remains negative and is forecasted to widen further in 2025 and 2026. The output gap was estimated at \(-0.8\%\) of GDP in 2Q25 (vs \(-1.5\%\) in the previous report and down from \(+0.4\%\) of GDP in 2Q24) and is projected to widen to \(-1.9\%\) by end-2025 \((-2.5\%\) in the previous report) and to \(-3.0\%\) by end-2026 (vs \(-3.6\%\) in the previous report).
3. The output gap ex-oil industry was marked at \(-1.0\%\) of GDP by Jun 2025, a notable shift from \(+0.6\%\) a year ago.

4. The labor market backdrop remains tight, but consumption markets are now operating with slack. A principal component analysis shows that the slack conditions in consumption markets remain in negative territory and that the labor market remains tight. By May-25, slack in consumption markets is estimated at \(-0.7\%\) \((-0.8\%\) at end-2024 and \(+0.1\%\) of GDP a year ago) and in the labor market at \(+0.8\%\) (little changed from the \(+1.0\%\) in Mar-24 cyclical high).
5. On the balance of risks for activity the QIR did not change:

a. Downside risks to activity: (1) intensification of global uncertainty; (2) lower-than-expected US growth; (3) bouts of volatility in domestic and global financial markets; (4) intensification of geopolitical conflicts; (5) higher-than-expected impact on activity of the reduction in government spending driven by the announced fiscal consolidation; and (6) negative weather shocks.

b. Upside risks to activity: (1) reduction of global uncertainty with respect to the US trade policy; (2) firmer-than-expected US activity; (3) enhanced leveraging of the USMCA and an increase in the competitiveness of certain products; (4) that within the framework of the USMCA, the repositioning of global supply chains end-up leveraging investment spending above expectations; and (5) higher-than-expected impulse from government spending.
c. The balance of risks for activity is skewed to the downside, vs "markedly skewed to the downside" in the previous QIR.

6. On inflation, the QIR forecasts were identical to those unveiled in the Aug 7 MPC meeting: headline inflation expected to reach \(3.7\%\) by end-2025 (core \(3.7\%\) ). Convergence to the \(3\%\) target expected by 3Q2026, which we deem as too rosy.
7. The QIR lists the broadly same five main upside and three main downside risks to the outlook for inflation as the Aug 7 MPC meeting.

a. As upside risks to inflation the MPC mentions: (1) FX depreciation; (2) geopolitical or trade policy disruptions; (3) persistence of core inflation; (4) increasing cost pressures; and (5) climate-related shocks.  
b. As downside risks to inflation the MPC again mentions: (1) lower-than-expected domestic or US economic activity; (2) lower pass-through of cost pressures; and (3) lower price pressures due to year-to-date MXN appreciation.

8. For the MPC the balance of risks for inflation around the projected path "remains biased to the upside" though less so than in 2021-2024. That notwithstanding, the MPC repeats that US economic policy changes have added uncertainty to the forecasts, and their effects could imply pressures on inflation on both sides of the balance of risks.
Central Bank Projected Inflation Path
Core Inflation (% yoy)
Source: Banxico, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Output Gap in Negative Territory in 2025-2026
Source: Banxico, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Labor Market More Resilient (Lagging) than Consumption Markets
Source: Banxico, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Mex-US Policy Rate Differential Continues to Tighten
Source: Banxico, FRB, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
